column1: Between 13 December 2019 and 1 May 2020, will either Moody's or S&P downgrade Bolivia's credit rating?
column6: ['Finance', 'Economic Policy']
Lowering chance as stable for a while, plus credt agencies have a lot of other thing on their plate on timings.
Moving back down a few points based on the surprising stability in Bolivia during the market's turn yesterday
With everyone hunkered down, working from home, and global threats to economic activity it's very doubtful action will be taken prior to the election.
The longer we go, the more stable Bolivia is looking (in Bolivian terms, of course). Decreasing chance that they'll be further downgraded before the election.
moving up a few percentage points based on overall market trends- still seems unlikely
Lowering. Probably waiting.
Lowering assessment. While I think the economic outlook will ultimately result in a downgrade, I agree with the opinion that it is likely to not happened until after the elections.
Lowering again based on election information and banks' analysis
Cut my rating in half given the weak arguments to the contrary.

- Going down 5% based on published research from MIT (a highly valid source) stating there was no indication that the Oct 2019 elections were illegitimate. While this may slightly increase the chance of Morales returning to Bolivia and attempting to wrest control from Anez, it seems more likely that the country will progress toward its scheduled 3 May elections. - The evidence that the election was legitimate indicates political and governmental stability - which creditors would hope to see, thus lessening the chance of their credit rating being further downgraded. - https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/02/centre-evidence-fraud-bolivia-october-polls-200228052717538.html
If Arce wins
Will likely get downgraded but not in this timeframe. It's getting too close to the Bolivian election.

Lowering estimate. S&P held Bolivia's credit rating at BB- on 16 December 2019. It's unlikely that they will review the rating again during the question's timeframe. on 22 January, Moody's announced the completion of its review of Bolivia's credit rating. However, I have not found the results of the report. My presumption, as there has been no change to the rating in the last 30 days, is that Moody's elected to hold Bolivia's credit rating. As with my assessment of S&P, it is unlikely that Moody's would undertake a second review within the question's timeframe. Though my assumption is that neither agency will lower Bolivia's credit rating in the given time frame, I am leaving a 19% probability based on current global economic conditions re: corona virus and its implications.

Question asked about both Moody’s and S&P. Kammel’s comments about lowered demand for Bolivia’s natural resources could hurt the economy are valid. Those comments about credit agencies waiting until after Bolivian election also seem to be a caution. S&P said outlook was negative but no change so far. Moody’s rated economy at Ba1 but made no change. Date for this is May 1.
About 2 months to go, wait until after the election would be the simplest and most correct path.
Increasing stability, so lowering forecast.

Found more information. The review did not involve the ‘rating committee’. However, the review said the economy supports a Ba1 rating. https://www.moodys.com/researchdocumentcontentpage.aspx?docid=PR_415443 That is higher than its Ba3 rating.
Thought Moody’s financial review finished Jan 23nd but can not find information on the results. Lowering. Yes Bolivia is stabilizing politically but damage to economy already done.

Updates: 1. Morales is now disqualified from the 3 May election for not actually living in Bolivia (https://www.aljazeera.com/news/2020/02/bolivia-court-disqualifies-morales-running-senate-200221065318034.html) 2. Given the Oct 2019 elections were deemed rigged, we can assume the 3 May election will have increased scrutiny from outside agencies 3. Recent polling suggests Morales' party is still the favorite (31.6%) and the two other opposition parties polling at 17% and 16%.
Revising down; more likely to wait until after elections

Bolivia's economy faces potential negative impacts from the corona virus, which raises the chances of a credit agency downgrade. Bolivia's largest exports are commodities, including natural gas, zinc, soy, gold, and silver. The global price of natural gas (which is already low), zinc, and soy are likely to be low over the next few months as China's imports of commodities have fallen precipitously due to the corona virus. The price of gold and sliver are harder to predict, but any positive impact is likely to be outweighed by the fall in prices of the other commodities.

Increasing to 15%. Moody's stated in December '19 (https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-places-Bolivias-Ba3-rating-under-review-for-downgrade--PR_403833) that "the review may extend beyond the usual three-month horizon as a longer time period may be required by the new government to define its policy agenda following another round of presidential elections."
Passage of time

I'm lowering this forecast by 1% due to the recent announcement in the Economist: "Jeanine Áñez, Bolivia’s interim president, announced that she would run for the presidency in May. A conservative former senator, she became president after Evo Morales quit in November. Critics of Ms Áñez say she should not run for office while also, as interim president, overseeing the election." I continue to assess that Moody's and S&P will wait until after the upcoming elections before downgrading.
Rated Ba3 but this report indicates economy only has Ba1 strength. Due for downgrade like Fitch’s did. https://www.moodys.com/researchdocumentcontentpage.aspx?docid=PR_415443

Trying to base rate this but don't know that I can. S&P has downgraded twice since 2011, basically 2 times in about 8 + years, starting me at roughly 25% . Presidential elections are scheduled for May 3 and I believe rating services will wait until after elections to reassess government's credit rating. Will stay at 25% and reassess.

The 20 Oct 2019 turmoil is fading. Morales has resigned and has committed not to run in the next elections, which are scheduled for 3 May. According to an article on the "Trading Economics" website, S&P and/ or Moody's will only further degrade credit rating if economic outlook is poor or if political turmoil worsens. Per a 21 Jan 2020 article on the Focus Economics website, they assess the economic outlook as flat. Considering there is currently an acting president, that legitimate elections are scheduled for 3 May, and that Morales will not participate, it seems less likely than so that there would be a reason to further degrade their credit score.

Since Fitch downgraded the credit rating in November, they have further reported that Bolivia has exhausted its international reserves. As Moody's is currently reviewing Bolivia's credit rating, this additional information may require Moody's to finalize the review vice delaying a decision.
I'll follow the analysis of @SharkAPC and @cm2310 and assume agencies will wait until the election before making a change.

According to moodys.com, Moody’s has rated Bolivia 10 times since 1998 and downgraded Bolivia once in 10 years. S&P has rated Bolivia 14 times since 2011 and has downgraded Bolivia 5 times according to https://countryeconomy.com/ratings/bolivia. As a result, I’m establishing the base rate at 20% (avg of Moody’s and S&P).

The macroeconomic risks of the Bolivian economy is the main driver. In terms of the numbers, the Economy is doing well but Bolivia’s long-term development problems remain, and the country’s insertion into the international economy is still a distant reality. GDP is expected 3,2% and it is likely expected no big change in the forecast. It is likely that Bolivian government will try to take some mesaures about the hydrocarbon exports and declining international reserves. But it is unlikely that they will solve the still-elevated political uncertainty and social tensions.
Less likely now that the Evangelical interim president has announce she is a candidate for president.
Lowering slightly after opposing parties laid ground rules for upcoming election, though agreement is fragile
Fitch did in November so it is likely. Country has elections coming up and Morales is calling off his militias so just maybe it will squeak by. Lowering some.

Political tension will persist for a while, African swine fever in China will decrease demand for soybean exports, oil prices are low - so national income will suffer in the near term. It is unclear that an incoming government could make things better soon, but they could make things worse.

We should all remember (do you?) that in the financial crisis of 2005-2009 S&P and Moody's were terrible in rating bonds several grades higher than they should have been and Fitch was much more realistic. I believe Fitch is more realistic today and I suspect S&P and Moody's know it too and will follow Fitch with downgrades without much delay.
Unrest in Populatioin

I think Moody's will follow S&P and Fitch with a downgrade, but the timing is difficult to determine. Moody's says "The review may extend beyond the usual three-month horizon as a longer time period may be required by the new government to define its policy agenda following another round of presidential elections (scheduled for 3 May)." https://www.moodys.com/research/Moodys-places-Bolivias-Ba3-rating-under-review-for-downgrade--PR_403833 https://tradingeconomics.com/bolivia/rating

S&P's ratings of Bolivia are trending negative but since 2011- all of their predictions for Bolivia came out after 1 May- so while the December downgrade occurred- traditionally they won't publish another rating until after 1 May so I rate this as a 8% possibility.

Though the credit rating agencies have a relatively dim view of the Bolivian economic outlook, it is unlikely that they will change anything before May 2020. The primary reason for this is the election on May 3rd: opinions are divided on Añez and Morales still enjoys a certain degree of popular support, so economic forecasters may be loath to cast any judgments until after the permanent president has been decided. Furthermore, Morales was removed for political rather than economic reasons, and so rating agencies would have to see a significant event in order to revise their ratings within the next 5 months.
Don't think they are going to call it before the election.
Bolivia is extremely unstable now.
It's very likely.
Uncertainty about the country's political leadership.
Lack of political security in the country.
Chaos & mismanagement, being landlocked
Gut.

When 3rd World Countries change major economic criteria, the number of people who can accept the government's reassurance are few. Those reasons vary from lack of understanding to corruption and guarantee the continuing downgrading.
guess

When writing my previous forecast elections were expected, but not set, in March or April. Elections have now been set for May 3rd.[1] Rating downgrade before this time seems very unlikely – probably will only occur before May 1st if the elections are delayed, or the interim government makes significant and bad economic choices. The interim government has invited help from the EU and USAID [2] which is likely to be seen as a positive by the ratings agencies, and reduce the probability of a pre-election downgrade.
Based on the negative outlook noted by S&P and Fitch as well as the continuing turmoil within the government.
Updating for passage of time.
Reducing with passage of time and proximity to election.
Trending for a negative outlook but score should not drop.
updating for passage of time
This is the crowd consensus
Bolivia appears to have been sliding downwards, and is slightly more likely to ontinue downwards,
Elections announced for May 3rd. Based on my understanding, this improves the case for a wait-and-see posture from the ratings agencies.
Moody’s reassessing right now. Evo is still leading what he terms as counter coup. Cocaine traders back Evo and do not want anything to upset the illicit trade. Power split will hurt economy.

Moody’s expect to downgrade Bolivia unless the government is willing and able to enact policies to prevent erosion of fiscal and foreign exchange reserve buffers. The rating is under review until after the new election (probably). S&P have a negative outlook.

While a downgrade is possible based on political tensions hitting economic fundamentals. (1) Those fundamentals (eg GDP, jobs, Central Bank, Debt) are relatively stable and not showing a marked deterioration. (2) There has been political peace offerings in terms of a possible election re-run (3) Ratings agencies take months to move to full downgrade and are unlikely to be swift when political resolution may occur and so a full downgrade by 1 May seems less likely to me.
Almost certainly. However, it may or may not be by May 1st.
Review of current forecasts and political situation

Moody's downgraded Bolivia once since 1998, in 2003, when Bolivia was experiencing political turmoil. Bolivia is now experiencing political turmoil and their credit rating is higher now than it was then. This inclines me to think downgrade is possible. S&P and Fitch agree that the outlook is "negative".

Media was already over enthusiastic about monetizing the Lithium deposits way before Coke Man got himself into problems. The country is way too Balkanized politically. Particularly cowboy country in Santa Cruz along the old RR to Sao Paulo who have sometimes wated to behave like a breakaway republik... One might conjecture that Evangeical crews have no economic guru who can forge respectable economic policy to gain repect of the pay to play ratings orgs.

The answer to this question will depend on the actions of the interim government and the time frame in which new elections are held. If new elections are NOT held, the credit rating is more likely to be downgraded.
There is more fear in the markets, than warrented by the actual situation

If the situation in Bolivia further destabilizes into civil war, yeah, it might happen. But the new government, on net, should mean Bolivia is more likely to meet its obligations, rather than continue on a Venezuelan-style spiral.
fun

S&P itself is quoted as saying that the outlook change reflects a 1-in-3 chance that the agency will downgrade the debt in the next 6-18 months (https://tradingeconomics.com/bolivia/rating). S&P also suggests in this paper on page 19 that a change in outlook usually means that the agency is concerned over the next 6-24 months, while adding the issuer to CreditWatch is more near-term (https://www.spratings.com/documents/20184/774196/Guide_to_Credit_Rating_Essentials_Digital.pdf).
Ba Obligations rated Ba are judged to be speculative and are subject to substantial credit risk. B Obligations rated B are considered speculative and are subject to high credit risk.
